bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Laura Armistead Carter, November 7, 1928

div1.p: Kean asks Laura Carter if her father's papers indicate the dates he arrived at and departed from Cuba, in 1900.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Laura Armistead Carter, November 7, 1928
div1.opener:
THE MILITARY SURGEON
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM
WASHINGTON
7 November, 1928.
Miss Laura Carter,
The Westmoreland,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
Some little time before the death of your
distinguished father I had occasion to look up some
incidents connected with Walter Reed's yellow fever work
and wrote to ask his recollection of this subject.
My recollection is that he said that he had left Havana
at that time. Can you, from your data, tell me when
he arrived at Havana and when he left? I remember
Major Reed's telling me in the autumn of 1900 of his
observations as to extrinsic incubation of yellow
fever, and my recollection was that he was in Havana
at that time, but I may be mistaken about that.

I hope you are getting along well with your
work.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN,
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd. JRK/F
